Key Match Events: Lane Thomas hit a three-run homer in a five-run outburst before Detroit got an out
Cleveland's bullpen combined for 4 1/3 hitless innings to finish and match the largest shutout victory margin in club postseason history
Pre-Game Insights: Tigers manager A.J. Hinch used his bullpen in Game 1 from the start and it backfired

Cleveland's relievers were as advertised with rookie Cade Smith striking out all four batters, Tim Herrin handling the seventh, Hunter Gaddis the eighth, and Emmanuel Clase, who led the AL with 47 saves, working the ninth
Post-Match Reflections: Tigers manager A.J. Hinch said, 'We're going to see a lot of this bullpen. The more you look at them, hopefully, the more comfortable you get.'
Guardians manager Stephen Vogt said, 'We came out ready to swing the bat, and we looked like we didn’t take five days off.'
Detroit's Zach McKinstry said, 'I tried to make a play and I didn't. We ended up losing the game because of it.'
Miscellaneous Highlights: Steven Kwan got it rolling with a leadoff double against Tigers starter Tyler Holton (0-1) and Fry walked
José Ramírez followed with a hard hopper to third that Zach McKinstry misplayed for an error, allowing Kwan to score
David Fry added a two-run double for the AL Central champion Guardians
Others: The 2,327th meeting between Detroit and Cleveland was the first between the franchises and Central division rivals in the postseason
The shutout was the worst in Detroit playoff history since Game 1 of the 1945 World Series
